awd_titl_txt: The Molecular Basis of Host Adaptation and Origin of New Mutualisms
awd_abstract_narration: Beneficial bacteria are the foundation of health in both plants and animals. Although disease-causing bacteria have received intensive scientific attention, the processes that drive the evolution of beneficial bacterial symbioses are still poorly understood. This project will apply the techniques and conceptual perspectives of molecular genetics, microbiology and evolutionary biology to document the genetic processes involved in evolution of beneficial symbiosis. The project will make use of an unusually tractable experimental model involving marine animals and their symbiotic bacteria: the symbiosis between bobtail squid and a light-producing bacterium, Vibrio fischeri. Some strains of Vibrio fischeri form life-long symbioses with squid and fish, whereas other strains are free-living in the marine environment. Exploiting the natural variation in this bacterium, the investigators will compare six V. fischeri strains with diverse environmental histories and differing initial capacities for colonization of squid hosts to identify bacterial mutations correlated with successful animal colonization, and with evolution of beneficial symbiotic interactions. This is among the first experimental evolution models, and the only natural model, to explore the mechanistic basis of beneficial host-adaptation in symbiotic microbes. The project includes interdisciplinary training for  several graduate and undergraduate students, and capitalizes upon an engaging model system to promote an understanding of evolution and of symbiosis among students at all educational levels. The project will also develop educational resources for middle and high school teachers, including  hands-on experiments using beneficial microbes in the classroom.

por.por_cntn:
Complex host-associated communities of bacteria that play a critical role in the normal function of all multicellular organisms and yet the processes that allow these associations to develop have been underappreciated and thus understudied. How resident bacteria and their hosts successfully enter into stable associations is poorly understood for all but a few host-microbe systems. And considering that a host letting its guard down to allow intimate association with a microbe could give entry to a pathogen, the recognition process must be highly-tuned to recognize and accommodate the right partner through toning down immune responses: recognition is key to prevent inappropriate immune responses to beneficial bacteria.

This research utilized the squid-Vibrio fischeri light organ symbioses as a model to reveal the evolutionary processes and molecular mechanisms that allow new beneficial bacterial associations to develop. Euprymna scolopes squid hatch symbiont free and must recruit bacteria from the surrounding seawater comprised of a plethora of diverse bacteria. Squid are exceptionally adept at recognizing symbiotic strains and exclude entry to the light organ of all bacteria except those that have co-evolved with them. The squid do this through multiple checkpoints, many of which are concerved across different species, and only some of which we understand. A bacterium must bypass successive roadblocks before reaching light organs where they are nourished by the host and upon reaching an optimal cell density produce light to protect the host from predation. Each morning, squid trim 95% of their light organ symbionts by venting some into the water to make room to re-grow the population, and through this cycling process re-seed the water with symbionts that either remain free-living or find new hosts. We used this natural process whereby squid serially culture bacteria and applied them in an experimental evolution approach to drive the evolution of non-symbiotic populations towards improved symbiosis, allowing us to document the evolutionary process of a new mutualism. We started with squid-naive strains of Vibrio fischeri with extremely poor starting capacity for association and serially passaged parallel populations through squid, allowing the squid to select for mutations that promote symbiosis. We used this to reveal the dynamics of evolving symbiosis. Virtually nothing was known about the order and kinds of mutational events that facilitate beneficial associations, largely because experimental models had not been developed. Analyzing the genomes of the winning symbionts and determining phenotypes of evolved lineages allowed us to compare the adaptive process of transitioning between similar squid hosts, switching from vertebrate to invertebrate hosts, and even specializing from a planktonic and potentially undifferentiated state to a squid host.

Our study revealed that starting symbiotic capacity, rather than past evolutionary experience strongly affected the trajectory of evolution of strains. Most surprisingly, the study revealed convergent mutations repeatedly arose in parallel evolving populations at a single ?adaptability? locus in a previously uncharacterized signal transduction pathway protein called BinK. These types of proteins pass information through a series of proteins and help cells integrate sensory information and coordinate actions by changing gene expression. Interestingly, evolution was promoted by gain of new function through an altered ability of BinK to partner with and change the response of other similar signal transduction proteins thereby changing multiple signaling pathways. This exemplifies how evolutionarily useful it can be to maintain some flexibility in signaling protein partnership allowing rapid adaptive evolution when bacteria encounter a new host or environment. Though there were many new findings, one of the most insightful outcomes of our study was the discovery that changes in biofilm which is a group behavior whereby bacteria stick together, provided a very strong selective advantage on a single cell, not population basis, most likely through the masking of antigens that allow host hemocytes- the protective immune cells of squid- to recognize and destroy foreign bacteria. The maintenance of loci such as that encoding BinK likely explain how some bacteria are so capable of rapidly expanding abilities to colonize new hosts.

The project advanced knowledge in multiple fields including symbiosis and host microbe interactions, genetics, genomics and importantly evolutionary biology. This research was disseminated to the public through a high-profile peer review publication (Pankey, Foxall et al. doi.org/10.7554/eLife.24412) and through multiple popular media outlets which promoted the importance of beneficial microbes and their study more broadly to the public. In addition to a postdoctoral scholar, three graduate and multiple undergraduate students received valuable training which included presenting their work in public seminars and at national and international scientific meetings. Educational materials in three undergraduate courses at the University of New Hampshire were developed from the project.
